awd_titl_txt: SpecEES: Toward Spectral and Energy Efficient Cross-Layer Designs for Millimeter-Wave-Based Massive MIMO Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Millimeter-wave (mmWave) and Massive MIMO (M-MIMO) technologies have strong potential to impact future 5G wireless networks and support data rates 50 times greater than the current 4G LTE wireless communications. As such, 5G multi-Gigabit wireless networks are poised to enable a myriad of applications for (e.g., Internet-of-Things, virtual/augmented reality, etc.). However, the highly directional propagation of mmWave signals and the special mmWave hardware requirements introduce fundamental technical challenges for mmWave-based M-MIMO network systems that may require a clean-slate of hardware and software beamforming architectures. In light of these challenges, the goal of this research program is to advance knowledge in both hardware design and theoretical foundations of mmWave and M-MIMO wireless networks. By exploring new hardware-software technologies for mmWave M-MIMO wireless networks, this research program is envisioned to serve a critical need in mmWave communications, signal processing, networking, and control research communities.  In terms of broader impacts, the PIs plan to incorporate findings into graduate courses and develop new special topic courses on the fundamentals of mmWave and M-MIMO communication networks. Engagement of undergrad and high school students is also planned with the aim to provide hands-on experience in RF components, communications, networking, control, and signal processing techniques.

The proposed research address foundational problems in mmWave large antenna arrays and communication networks, with potential breakthroughs in both theory and practice to enable the success of on future multi-Gigabit wireless communications and associated networking applications. This research program spans broad areas of communications and signal processing to establish a network-level understanding of mmWave M-MIMO networks through a unified research program, which includes the development and exploration of: i) tractable theoretical models, ii) theoretical performance bounds and capacity limits, and iii) low-complexity algorithms.  The novelty of this project lies in the joint beam training and scheduling algorithms through the introduction of novel algorithms in the radio-frequency front-end, and in the exploitation of subarray clustering to increase throughput and reduce energy consumption. The PIs' efforts are organized around three interdependent research thrusts: i)  Transceiver and beamforming architectures that offer large agility in frequency tuning and high performance at several metrics, ii) Spectral-efficiency optimization algorithms based on mmWave-based subarray clustering,  and iii) Energy-efficiency scheduling algorithms based on mmWave-based subarray clustering. In addition to theoretical studies, the PIs plan to validate the analytical techniques and models via extensive simulations, trace-driven emulations, and field tests.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, our goal is to investigate the control and optimization of spectral and energy efficient algorithms for mmWave cellular networks based on on-site code division multiplexing, and using a novel massive MIMO transceiver and beamforming hardware architecture. Millimeter waves and Massive MIMO technologies have tremendous potential to make a significant impact on future 5G wireless networks, which is expected to support data rates 50 times over the current 4G LTE networks. The future 5G multi-Gigabit wireless communication technologies are poised to enable a myriad of networking applications for (e.g., Internet-of-Things, virtual/augmented reality, just to name a few). Our proposed research program advances the knowledge in both hardware design and the theoretical foundation of mmWave and M-MIMO wireless networks. Also, our proposed research serves a critical need in the broadly defined communications, signal processing, networking, and control research communities by exploring a joint hardware-software understanding and development of mmWave-based massvie MIMO wireless networks. Our research program consists of: i) hybrid OS-CDM/Diplo-FIRE transceiver and beamforming architecture, ii) Spectral-efficient optimization through OS-CDM/Diplo-FIRE subarray clustering, and iii) Energy-efficient optimality through OS-CDM/Diplo-FIRE subarray clustering. Our proposed research leveraged the latest advances in mmWave-based massive MIMO communications at the physical layer to enable new wireless network optimization opportunities. Our novelty in this project lies in the joint beam training and scheduling algorithms through the OS-CDM RF frond-end subarray clustering to increase throughput and reduce energy consumption.

The lifetime of this award can be roughly divided into two stages. In the first stage of the award, we focus on developing fast-converging and low-delay joint congestion control and scheduling algorithms for single-hop and multi-hop mmWave-based wireless networks, which are cross-layer in the protocol stack. Our works in this stage leveraged momentum information in cross-layer design to accelerate the convergence speed of joint congestion control and scheduling, which entails high-throughput and low-delay. We also showed that the use of higher-order momentum information can continue to improve the delay performance. Based on these momentum-based approaches, we further investigated the impacts of limited channel state information in mmWave-based wireless networks on congestion control and scheduling. We showed that there is a “phase transition” phenomenon of the networking performance in terms of the channel state information accuracy. Also, in this stage of this project, we investigated the medium access control layer and considered low-overhead uplink scheduling algorithms over mmWave-based massive MIMO systems. Specifically, we characterized the capacity outer bound of these mmWave physical layers subject to the unique constraints of mmWave. The insights obtained from our proposed algorithms allowed us to develop an efficient and low-overhead wireless resource allocation and scheduling algorithms to satisfy the unique mmWave physical layer constraints with theoretical performance guarantees.

In the second stage of this project, with the rise of machine learning and artificial intelligence during this project period, our research gradually evolved toward studying related distributed, federated, and decentralized optimization and control approaches for single- and multi-hop mmWave-based wireless networks, which in turn have applications gearing more toward a variety of machine learning paradigms over mmWave-based wireless networks. The paradigms of distributed and federated learning are based on single-hop mmWave-based cellular wireless networks, while the paradigm of decentralized learning is based on multi-hop mmWave-based wireless networks. In each learning paradigm, we have further considered a large class of optimization problems, including finite-sum or expectation minimization, min-max, and bilevel optimization that can be applied for mmWave network optimization. In federated learning, we have focused on developing fast-converging algorithmic techniques that work well under both system and data heterogeneity. We have incorporated momentum and variance reduction techniques and bilevel Hessian-approximation to accelerate the convergence rate of the proposed algorithms, which lead to low sample and communication complexities for the proposed optimization algorithms. We also developed momentum, variance reduction, and bilevel algorithmic techniques for fully decentralized learning problems, which enjoy significant sample-communication complexity reductions for solving these network optimization problems.
